Award.AwardTitle: SGER: The Impact of Extreme Flooding on Mussel and Microbial Nutrient Dynamics at the Water-Sediment Interface
Award.AbstractNarration: Introduction: This proposal is prepared in response to the devastating floods in Eastern Iowa and nearly<br/>the entire Upper Mississippi River (UMR) basin during May-July 2008. In UMR Pool 16, above Lock and<br/>Dam 16 at Muscatine, Iowa, waters abruptly rose from a highly managed stage of approximately 10 feet<br/>to 20 feet and then to nearly 24 feet from May-June 2008. This historic flood event coincided with<br/>intense spring cultivation and nutrient application activities in the heavily farmed landscape of the<br/>Upper Midwest resulting in a significant pulse of agricultural contaminants to the UMR system. This has<br/>led scientists to predict an almost unprecedented delivery of sediment and nutrients to Pool 16, the<br/>broader Mississippi River and the Gulf of Mexico.<br/>This event presents a unique, and short-lived, opportunity to test scientific hypotheses related to a<br/>highly perturbed, large river ecosystem. This ecosystem of braided channels and natural backwaters is<br/>already known to inadequately process nutrients such as nitrate to the degree required to protect the<br/>Gulf from hypoxic episodes. Extreme, flood-related sediment deposition almost certainly impacts the<br/>nutrient processing cycle in the short and long term. It is also known that mussels and bacteria play a<br/>major role in nutrient cycling in the broad food web containing phytoplankton, zooplankton, microzooplankton,<br/>dissolved & particulate organic matter, and benthos. Given this confluence of events, and<br/>the importance of understanding nutrient cycling, we wish to test the following hypothesis:<br/>Intense deposition of particulate organic matter from extreme flooding alters the freshwater mussel and<br/>microbial food webs through physical and chemical means.<br/>Immediate Need: The principal investigators feel this hypothesis can only be tested via the quickresponse<br/>Small Grants for Exploratory Research (SGER) funding mechanism since the highly perturbed<br/>ecosystem in question is actively returning to more steady-state conditions. The research team must be<br/>deployed very soon to study the perturbed nitrogen cycling rates such that comparisons with baseline<br/>nitrogen processing rates can be made in the future.<br/>Broader Impacts: Floods occur around the world on a regular basis, but the frequency and extremity of<br/>these events will increase given the influence of global climate change. This research will contribute to<br/>the development of a ?theory of floods? that is proposed by colleagues at the University of Iowa. This<br/>theory will seek to unify research related to hydrology, ecology, socio-economic, environmental and<br/>human consequences and influences on flooding. The impact of such research can be expressed in<br/>billions of dollars, millions of acres of habitat, thousands of species, and centuries of human enjoyment.<br/>Intellectual Merit: This research will expand our knowledge of large river nutrient processing dynamics<br/>resulting from extreme flooding events and during baseline moments. Abrupt changes in nutrient<br/>loading and extreme shifts in algal compositions can influence food quality which may adversely affect<br/>desirable and invasive freshwater mussels. This work will further characterize the relation between<br/>nutrient conditions and food quality for mussels and other biota in an important reach of the Upper<br/>Mississippi River. Water quality, nutrients, and their effects of biological processes are key management<br/>concerns in the Upper Mississippi River.
